awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Foundations of Quantitative Thought: Number, Space, Time, and Probability
awd_abstract_narration:
Humans have an innate ability to estimate quantities yet their intuitions often contain biases that interfere with learning new ways to think about quantity. Weaving together strands of psychology, neuroscience, economics, and education, researchers at Wesleyan University and Boston College shed light on the cognitive processes underlying our abilities to estimate 4 kinds of quantities: number, space, time, and probability. By comparing processes across these four distinct areas, the researchers aim to provide a unifying account of how children and adults estimate quantities, which has the potential to transform current understanding of the cognitive bases of how people learn in and across STEM disciplines. Achieving a simple unifying account is important because the ability to think well about quantity in all of these areas is fundamental to STEM learning. Other educational benefits include the establishment of partnerships with local museums that allow the research team to collect data from a diverse population while also supporting the museum's public education efforts. This project also contributes to STEM workforce development by training undergraduate students through a service-learning course offered at Wesleyan, and through a summer research internship exchange across the two universities. These aspects of the project, taken with its robust theoretical grounding, well-formulated research questions and tests of competing models of how people reason about quantity in childhood and adulthood, demonstrate its potential to guide and improve the design of STEM learning environments for all citizens.

This project exemplifies the Education and Human Resources Core Research program's commitment to fundamental research on learning in STEM that combines theory, techniques, and perspectives from a wide range of disciplines and contexts.  Specifically, it aims to provide a unifying account of how children and adults estimate quantities across four distinct domains: the development of numerical estimation; spatial categorization (remembering the location of items in space); the theoretical neuroscience of time processing (reproducing temporal durations); and decision making under risk (the processing of probabilities). Through a series of behavioral studies with adults and children, the researchers will test their hypothesis that proportion judgment underlies basic quantity estimation across these domains, across development, and across contexts (varying task constraints). This work is important because -- despite striking similarities in behaviors described across research in these literatures -- each one conceptualizes them quite differently, positing different accounts of the underlying mechanisms that yield quantity judgments. The project will advance and potentially transform our understanding of mental representations and processes involved in quantity judgments while also providing insight into how quantity biases may influence the processing of numerical information in educational contexts and real-life decisions. In this way the project builds a coherent, cumulative knowledge base, focusing on high-leverage topics.

por.por_cntn:
When people think about quantities like space, time, and number, they're often drawing on a cognitive system that uses "mental magnitudes" to represent these quantities in their minds. Even infants and nonhuman animals can use this system to think about quantities in an intuitive, approximate way. The mental magnitude system is theoretically important to cognitive science to learn about how quantitative thinking emerges and develops, about the kinds of thinking that can happen without language, and about the way concepts may change with learning and development. Investigating how mental magnitudes underlie quantitative thinking is also important for its educational implications. Our early-emerging intuitive quantitative abilities aren't replaced by formal education. Instead, they influence many aspects of quantitative thinking and learning, reasoning, and decision making throughout childhood and into adulthood. In recent years, a large body of work has explored links between intuitive quantitative processing and STEM ability and achievement. A better understanding of intuitive quantitative abilities is key to understanding cognitive processes underlying STEM thinking and learning.

The broad research goal of this project was to develop our basic scientific understanding of human quantitative thinking across contexts. We identified a set of distinct but related tasks that all involve different types of judgments about quantity. These tasks were drawn from four separate research literatures: the development of numerical estimation (translating between different types of quantities); the role of categorization in cognition (remembering and reproducing magnitudes, focusing on spatial extent); time processing (remembering and reproducing magnitudes, focusing on temporal duration); and decision making under risk (using quantities embedded within broader problems, focusing on the representation of probability). Although there are striking similarities across these four kinds of judgments, they have been conceptualized quite differently within their respective literatures, yielding different theoretical accounts of the underlying cognitive processes. A major underlying concept in this project is the idea that quantity estimates across domains are governed by a similar process of proportion estimation. This project aimed to explore a theoretical framework based on proportion estimation that could provide a unifying account of the cognitive processes that shape quantity judgments under a variety of conditions.

We conducted a series of experiments in which adults and children completed tasks that involve judgments of number, space, time, and probability. We tested the proposed framework in the domain of simple spatial judgments and found evidence suggesting that these judgments, and perhaps many others that lead to similar performance patterns, could indeed arise from a process of proportion estimation. In the domain of numerical cognition, our work connected the theoretical framework based on proportion estimation with children's math ability as measured by standardized tests. Considerable prior research shows that math ability is correlated with performance on simple numerical estimation tasks using number lines. We explored potential sources of this link from the perspective of the proportion estimation framework, describing how two key components of the quantitative model associated with the framework predict performance on assessments of math ability in elementary school children. In the domain of decision making, we have proposed that the psychophysics of probability use can be understood as a special case of the psychophysics of proportion judgment more broadly. Our mathematical model of decision making under risk, developed as part of this project, is published and disseminated for use by the community. The new framework has also opened up promising directions for future decision-making research, and has contributed to recent questioning of longstanding assumptions. The project makes contributions towards critical future development of explanations of decision behavior that have links to more basic cognitive processes.

This project contributes to the goal of advancing our understanding of mental representations and processes involved in quantity judgments that are foundational to STEM cognition and learning. It also provides insight into the cognitive processing of numerical information in educational contexts and real-life decisions. Additional activities also contributed substantially to societal goals while supporting and complementing the empirical work. Numerous undergraduates, postgraduates, and postdoctoral researchers received intensive training in all stages of the research process as part of this project. Finally, collaborative partnerships between educational institutions (such as science museums) and research groups provided, and continue to provide, opportunities for researchers to educate public audiences about both established developmental science and about active research projects.
